ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I feel like I have a much better understanding of how to approach scientific literature after this course.

This course pushed me intellectually in that I was forced to think about the world through a new lens of empirical knowledge; massive improvement in writing (especially in writing concise scientific papers); gained insights into (of course) the evolution of the human diet

Insight into current debate on the evolution of human diet (importance of meat eating vs starches vs cooking, etc.), different lines of evidence (fossil record, hunter gatherers, experimental archaeology, etc.), and bioenergetics.
This course significantly improved my analytical scientific writing and taught me to better compare different viewpoints in the literature.

I learned so much about how humans co-evolved with food: what types of food we ate, how we know about these things, some of the main debates around the subject (ex: whether meat eating made is human, what is the paleo diet, etc), how our metabolism works, and what we should eat to be healthy.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is a great survey of how (and why) the human diet evolved the way that it did. The course had ample space for a healthy amount of failure because there were so many assignments. Personally, I would have enjoyed a slightly more chronological approach to the subjects, but overall the syllabus was very well-arranged.

Strengths: small discussion based seminar, readings were very current, felt comfortable to ask questions, critique, dive deeper into topics, etc. Weaknesses: sometimes easy to get off topic, but not overall in a problematic way.

strengths: discussions were very interesting, structure of the course was very clear, small class size was great, topics were very well chosen
weaknesses: the essays were very analytical. You had to follow a very specific structure and that was constraining.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes! Although the workload is a bit high (probably about 80 pages of reading per week, four papers, and a long final paper), I personally enjoyed the challenge and felt that I became much faster at reading anthropology and archaeology papers in the process. The topic area is really interesting, and I always had new information to tell my friends that changed the way that I saw the world!
Yes, if you have an interest in human evolution or in broader topics related to diet like global health/public health, agriculture, etc. Highly reccommend for anthro majors.
Absolutely. This class was not only fascinating, but helped me develop important writing and analysis skills.

DEFINITELY YES. You learn so much about what food is good for you, how we burn calories, optimal macronutrient proportions, the impact different foods have on our development, etc. So many applications to your personal life. Also, Thompson is super chill. I do recommend doing the readings - the entire class is just using them as a jumping-off point for discussion.
